name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: with the profile.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 52Guidance on Obtaining and Retaining Beneficial Ownershi p Information, was issued by FinCEN, Board of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Governors of the Federal Reserve System, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, National Credit Union

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Administration, Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, Office of Thrift Supervision, and Securities and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Exchange Commission, in consultation with the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission, in May 2010.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The guidance consolidates existing regulatory expectations for obtaining beneficial ownership information for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: certain accounts and customer relationships .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Customer Due Diligence — Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  59 11/17/2014   Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Customer Due Diligence

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the appropriateness and comprehensiveness of the bank ’s customer due

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: diligence (CDD) policies, procedures, and processes for obtaining customer information and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assess the value of this information in detecting, monitoring, and reporting suspicious

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 1. Determine whether the bank ’s CDD policies, procedures, and p rocesses are

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: commensurate with the bank ’s risk profile .  Determine whether the bank has processes in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: place for obtaining information at account opening, in addition to ensuring current customer information is maintained.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 2. Determine whether policies, procedures, and processes allow for changes to a customer ’s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: risk rating or profile .  Determine who is responsible for reviewing or approving such

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: changes.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 3. Review the enhanced due diligence procedures and processes the bank uses to identify customers that ma y pose higher risk for money laundering or terrorist financing.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 4. Determine whether the bank provides guidance for documenting analysis associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the due diligence process, including guidance for resolving issues when insufficient

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: information or ina ccurate information is obtained.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Transaction  Testing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 5. On the basis of a risk assessment, prior examination reports, and a review of the bank’ s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: audit findings, sample CDD information for higher -risk customers .  Determine whether

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the bank collects appropri ate information and effectively incorporates this information

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: into the suspicious activity monitoring process .  This sample can be performed when

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: testing the bank ’s compliance with its policies, procedures, and processes as well as when

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reviewing transacti ons or accounts for possible suspicious activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 6. On the basis of examination procedures completed, including transaction testing, form a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: conclusion about the adequacy of policies, procedures, and processes associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: CDD.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  60 11/17/2014  Suspicious Activity Reporting —  Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the bank ’s policies, procedures, and processes, and overall compliance

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: with statutory and regulatory requirements for monitoring, detecting, and reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious activities.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious activity reporting forms the cornerstone of the BSA reporting system .  It is critical

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to the United States ’ ability to utilize financial information to combat terrorism, terrorist

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: financing, money laundering, and other financial crimes .  Examiners and banks should

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: recognize that the quality of SAR content is critical to the adequacy and effectiveness of the suspicious activity reporting system.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Within this system, FinCEN and the federal banking agencies recognize that, as a  practical

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: matter, it is not possible for a bank to detect and report all potentially illicit transactions that

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: flow through the bank.  Examiners should focus on evaluating a bank ’s policies, procedures,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and processes to identify , evaluate,  and report  susp icious activity .  However, as part of the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: examination process, examiners should review individual SAR filing decisions to determine the effectiveness of the bank’s suspicious activity identification, evaluation,  and reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: process .  Banks, bank holding companies, and their subsidiaries are required by federal

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: regulations

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 53 to file a SAR with respect to:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Criminal violations involving insider abuse in any amount.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Criminal violations aggregating $5,000 or more when a suspect can be identified.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Criminal viola tions aggregating $25,000 or more regardless of a potential suspect.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Transactions conducted or attempted by, at, or through the bank (or an affiliate) and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: aggregating $5,000 or more, if the bank or affiliate knows, suspects, or has reason to

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspect that t he transaction:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: – May involve potential money laundering or other illegal activity (e.g., terrorism financing).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: – Is designed to evade the BSA or its implementing regulatio ns.55

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: – Has no business or apparent lawful purpose or is not the type of transaction that  the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: particular customer would normally be expected to engage in, and the bank knows of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: no reasonable explanation for the transaction after examining the available facts,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: including the background and possible purpose of the transaction.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: A transaction inclu des a deposit; a withdrawal; a transfer between accounts; an exchange of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: currency; an extension of credit; a purchase or sale of any stock, bond, certificate of deposit,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 53 Refer to 12 CFR 208.62, 211.5(k), 211.24(f), and 225.4(f) (Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: System)  (Federal Reserve) ; 12 CFR 353 (Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation) (FDIC); 12 CFR 748 (National

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Credit Union Administration) (NCUA) ; 12 CFR 21.11 and 12 CFR 163.180 (Office of the Comptroller of the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Currency) (OCC) ; and 31 CFR 1020.320 (FinCEN).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 54 FinCEN issued guidance identifying certain BSA expectations for banks offering services to marijuana -

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: related businesses, including expectations for fil ing SARs , FIN-2014- G001, February 14, 2014.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 55 Refer to Appendix G (“Structuring”) for additional guidance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  61 11/17/2014  or other monetary instrument or investment security; or any other payment, transfer, o r

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: delivery by, through, or to a bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Safe Harbor for Banks F rom Civil Liability for Suspicious Activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Federal law (31 USC 5318(g)(3)) provides protection from civil liability for all reports of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious transactions made to appropriate authorities, including supporting documentation, regardless of whether such reports are filed pursuant to the SAR instructions .  Specifically,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the law provides that a bank and its directors, officers, employees, and agents that make a disclosure to the appropri ate authorities of any possible violation of law or regulation,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: including a disclosure in connection with the preparation of SARs, “ shall not be liable to any

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: person under any law or regulation of the United States, any constitution, law, or regulation of any State or political subdivision of any State, or under any contract or other legally enforceable agreement (including any arbitration agreement), for such disclosure or for any failure to provide notice of such disclosure to the person who is the subjec t of such disclosure

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: or any other person identified in the disclosure.”  The safe harbor applies to SARs filed within

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the required reporting thresholds as well as to SARs filed voluntarily on any activity below

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the threshold.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Systems to Identify,  Research,  and Report

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious activity monitoring and reporting are  critical internal controls .  Proper monitoring

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and reporting processes are essential to ensuring that the bank has an adequate and effective

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: BSA c ompliance p rogram .  Appropriate policies, procedures, and processes should be in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: place to monitor and identify unusual activity .  The sophistication  of monitoring systems

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: should be dictated by the bank’ s risk  profile , with particular emphasis on the composition of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: higher -risk products, services, customers, entities, and geographi es.  The bank should ensure

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: adequate staff is assigned to the identification, research, and reporting of suspicious activities , taking into account the bank’ s overall risk profile and the volume of tra nsactions .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Monitoring systems typically include employee identification or referrals, transaction -based

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: (manual) systems, surveillance (automated) systems , or any combination of these.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Generally, effective suspicious activity monitoring and reporting syst ems include f ive key

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: components ( refer to Appendix S “ Key Suspicious Activity Monitoring Components ”).  The

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: components, listed below, are interdependent, and an effective suspicious activity monitoring

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and reporting process should include successful implem entation of each component .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Breakdowns in any one or more of these components may adversely affect  SAR reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and BSA compliance .  The f ive key components to an effective monitoring and reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: system are:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 56 The agencies incorporated the statutory expansion of the safe harbor by cross -referencing section

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 5318(g)  in their SAR regulations .  The OCC and Fi nCEN amended their SAR regulations  to make clear

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: that the safe harbor also applies to a disclosure by a bank made jointly with another financial institution for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: purposes of filing a joint SAR  (see 12 CFR 21.11(l) and 31 C FR 1020.320(e)), respectively.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  62 11/17/2014  • Identification or alert of unusual activity (which may include: employee identification,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: law enforcement inquiries, other referrals, and transaction and surveillance monitoring

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: system  output ).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Managing alerts.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • SAR decision making.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • SAR completion and filing.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Monitoring and SAR filing on continuing activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: These components are present in banks of all sizes .  However, the structure and formality of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the components may vary .  Larger banks typically have greater differentiation and distinction

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: between functions, and may devote entire departments to the  completion of each component .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Smaller banks may use one or more employees to complete several tasks (e.g., review of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: monitoring reports, research activity, and completion of the actual SAR) .  Policies,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: procedures, and processes should describe the steps the bank takes to address each component and indicate the person(s) or departments responsible for identifying or producing an alert of unusual activity, managing the alert, deciding whether to file, SAR completion

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and filing , and monitoring and SAR filing  on continuing activity .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Identification of Unusual Activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks use a number of methods to identify potentially suspicious activity, including but not

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: limited to activity identified by employees during day -to-day operations, law enforcement

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: inquiries , or requests, such as those typically seen in section 314(a) and section 314(b)

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: requests, advisories issued by regulatory or law enforcement agencies, transaction and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: surveillance monitoring system output , or any combination of these.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Employee Identification

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: During the course of day -to-day operations, employees may observe unusual or potentially

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious transaction activity .  Banks should implement appropriate training, policies, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: procedures to ensure that personnel adhere to the  internal processes for identification and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: referral of potentially suspicious activity .  Banks should be aware of all methods of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identification and should ensure that their suspicious activity monitoring system includes

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: processes to facilitate the transfer  of internal referrals to appropriate personnel for further

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: research.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Law Enforcement Inquiries and Requests

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks should establish policies, procedures, and processes for identifying subjects of law enforcement requests, monitoring the transaction activit y of those subjects when appropriate,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identifying unusual or potentially suspicious activity related to those subjects, and filing, as appropriate, SARs related to those subjects .  Law enforcement inquiries and requests can

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: include grand jury subpoenas, N ational S ecurity Letters (NSL ), and section 314(a) requests.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 57 Refer to core overview section, “Information Sharing,” page 92, for a discussion on section 314(a) requests.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  63 11/17/2014  Mere receipt of any law enforcement inquiry does not, by itself, require the filing of a SAR

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: by the bank .  Nonetheless, a law enforcement inquiry may be relevant to a bank’s overall risk

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assessme nt of its customers and accounts .  For example, the receipt of a grand jury subpoena

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: should cause a bank to review account activity for the relevant customer.58 A bank should

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assess all of the information it knows about its customer, including the receipt of a law

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: enforcement inquiry, in accordance with its risk- based BSA/AML compliance program.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The bank should determine whether a SAR should be filed based on all customer information

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: available.  Due  to the confidentiality of grand jury proceedings, if a bank files a SAR after

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: receiving a grand jury subpoena, law enforcement discourages banks from including any

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reference to the receipt or existence of the grand jury subpoena in the SAR .  Rather, the SAR

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: should reference only those facts and activities that support a finding of suspicious

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transactions identified by the bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: National Security Letters

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: NSLs are written investigative demands that may be issued by the local Federal Bureau of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Investigation (FBI) and other federal governmental authorities in counteri ntelligence and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: counterterrorism investigations to obtain the following:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Telephone and electronic communications records from telephone companies and Internet service providers.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Information from credit bureaus.60

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Financial records from financial institutio ns.61

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: NSLs are highly confidential  documents ; for that reason , examiners do not review or sample

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: specific NSLs .62 Pursuant to 12 USC 3414(a)(3) and (5)(D), no bank, or officer, employee or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: agent of the institution, can disclose to any person that a government authority or the FBI has sought or obtained access to records through a Right to Financial Privacy Act NSL .  Banks

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: that receive NSLs must take appropriate measures to ensure the confidentiality of the letters and should have procedures in place for proce ssing and maintaining the confidentiality of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: NSLs.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: If a bank files a SAR after receiving a NSL, the SAR should not contain any reference to the receipt or existence of the NSL .  The SAR should reference only those facts and activities

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: that support a finding of unusual or suspicious transactions identified by the bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Questions regarding NSLs should be directed to the bank’ s local FBI field office .  Contact

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: information for the  field offices can be found at www.fbi.gov

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 58 Bank Secrecy Act Advisory Group, “Section 5 — Issues and Guidance” The SAR Activity Review –  Trends,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Tips & Issues, Issue 10, May 2006, pages 42 –  44, on the  FinCEN Web site .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 59 Electronic Communications Privacy Act, 18 USC 2709.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 60 Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 USC 1681u.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 61 Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978, 12 USC 3401 et seq.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 62 Refer to the Bank Secrecy Act Advisory Group, The SAR Activity Review —  Trends, Tips & Issues, Issue 8,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: April 2005 for further information on NSLs which is available on the  FinCEN Web site .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  64 11/17/2014  Transaction Monitoring ( Manual Transaction Monitoring )

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: A transaction monitoring system, sometimes referred to as a  manual transaction monitoring

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: system , typically target s specific types of transaction s (e.g. , those involving large amounts of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: cash, those to  or from foreign geographies)  and includes a manual  review of various reports

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: generated by the bank ’s MIS or vendor systems  in order  to identify unusual activity .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Examples of MIS reports include currency activity reports, funds transfer reports, monetary

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: instrument sales reports, large item reports, significant balance change reports, ATM transaction reports, and no nsufficient funds (NSF) reports .  Many MIS or vendor systems

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: include filtering models for identification of potentially unusual activity .  The process may

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: involve review of daily reports, reports that cover a period of time (e.g., rolling 30- day

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reports, monthly reports), or a combination of both types of reports .  The type and frequency

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of reviews and resulting reports used should be commensurat e with the bank ’s BSA/AML

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: risk profile and appropriately cover its higher -risk products, services, customers, entities, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: geographic locations.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: MIS or vendor system -generated reports typically use a discretionary dollar threshold.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Thresholds selected by  management for the production of transaction reports should enable

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: management to detect unusual activity .  Upon identification of unusual activity, assigned

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: personnel should review CDD and other pertinent information to determine whether the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activity is s uspicious .  Management should periodically evaluate the appropriateness of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: filtering criteria and thresholds used in the monitoring process .  Each bank should evaluate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and identify filtering criteria most appropriate for their bank .  The  programming of the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank’ s monitoring systems should be independently reviewed for reasonable filtering criteria .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Typical transaction monitoring reports are as follows.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Currency activity reports .  Most vendors offer reports that identify all currency activity or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: currency activity greater than $10,000.  These reports assist bankers with filing CTRs  and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identifying suspicious currency activity .  Most bank information service providers offer

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: currency activity reports that can filter transactions using various parameters, for example:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Currency activity including multiple transactions greater than $10,000.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Currency activity (single and multiple transactions) below the $10,000 reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: requirement (e.g., between $7,000 and $10,000).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Currency transactions involving multiple lower  dollar transactions (e.g., $3,000) that over

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: a period of time (e.g., 15 days) aggregate to a substantial sum of money (e.g., $30,000).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Currency transactions aggregated by customer name , taxpayer identification number , or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customer information file number .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Such filtering reports, whether implemented through a purchased vendor software system or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: through requests from information service providers, significantly enhance a bank’ s ability to

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identify and evaluate unusual currency transactions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Funds transfer records .  The BSA requires banks to maintain records of funds transfer in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: amounts of $3,000 and above .  Periodic review of this information can assist banks in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identifying patterns of unusual activity .  A periodic review of the funds transfer records in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: banks  with low funds transfer activity is usually sufficient to identify unusual activity .  For

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  65 11/17/2014  banks with more significant funds transfer activity, use of spreadsheet or vendor software is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: an efficient way to review funds transfer activity for unusual patterns .  Most vendor software

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: systems include standard suspicious activity filter reports .  These reports typically focus on

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identifying certain higher -risk geographic locations and larger dollar funds transfer

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transactions for individuals and businesses .  Each bank should establish its own filtering

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: criteria for both individuals and businesses .  Noncustomer funds transfer transactions and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: payable upon proper identification (PUPID) transactions should be reviewed for unusual activity .  Activities identified durin g these reviews should be subjected to additional research

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to ensure that identified activity is consistent with the stated account purpose and expected activity .  Whe n inconsistencies are identified, banks may need to conduct a global

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: relationship review to determine if a SAR is warranted .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Monetary instrument records .  Records for monetary instrument sales are required by the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: BSA .  Such records can assist the bank in identifying possible currency structuring through

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the purchase of cashier ’s checks, offici al bank checks, money orders, or traveler ’s checks in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: amounts of $3,000 to $10,000.  A periodic review of these records can also help identify frequent purchasers of monetary instruments and common payees .  Reviews for suspicious

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activity should encompass activity for an extended period of time (30, 60, 90 days) and should focus on, among other things, identification of commonalities, such as common

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: payees  and purchasers, or consecutively numbered purchased monetary instruments.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Surveillance Monitoring ( Automated Account Monitoring)

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: A surveillance monitoring system, sometimes referred to as an automated account monitoring

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: system, can cover multiple types of transactions and use  various rules to identify potentially

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious activity .  In addition, many can  adapt over time based on historical activity,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: trends, or internal peer comparison.  These systems typically use computer programs, developed in- house or purchased from vendors, to identify individual transactions, patterns

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of unusual activity, or deviations from expected activity .  These systems can capture a wide

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: range of account activity, such as deposits, withdrawals, funds transfers, automated clearing house (ACH) transactions, and automated teller machine (ATM) transactions, directly from the bank’ s core data processing system .  Banks that are large, operate in many locations, or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: have a large volume of higher -risk customers typically use surveillance monitoring systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Surveillance monitoring  systems include rule -based and intelligent systems .  Rule -based

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: systems detect unusual transactions that are outside of system -developed or management -

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: established “ rules. ” Such systems can consist of few or many rules, depending on the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: complexity of the in -house or vendor product .  These rules are applied using a series of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transaction filters or a rules engine.  Rule -based systems are more sophisticated than the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: basic manual system, which only filters on one rule (e.g., transaction greater than $10,000) .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Rule -based systems can apply multiple rules, overlapping rul es, and filters  that are more

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: complex .  For example, rule -based systems can initially apply a rule, or set of criteria to all

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: accounts  within a bank (e.g., all retail customers) , and then apply a more refined set of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: criteria to a subset of accounts or risk  category of accounts ( e.g., all retail customers with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: direct deposits ).  Rule -based systems can also filter  against  individual customer -account

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: profiles.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  66 11/17/2014  Intelligent systems are adaptive and can filter transactions, based  on historical account

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activity or  compare customer activity against a pre -established peer group or other relevant

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: data.  Intelligent systems review transactions in context with other transactions and the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customer profile .  In doing so, these systems increase their information database on the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customer, account type, category, or business, as more transactions and data are stored in the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: system.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Relative to surveillance monitoring, s ystem capabilities and thresholds refer to the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: parameters or filters used by banks in their monitoring process es.  Parameters and filters

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: should be reasonable and tailored to the activity that the bank is trying to identify or control .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: After parameters and filters have been developed, they should be reviewed before

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: implementation to identify any gaps (common mone y laundering techniques or frauds) that

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: may not have been addressed.  For example, a bank may discover that its filter for cash structuring is triggered only by a daily cash transaction in excess of $10,000.  The bank may need to refine this filter in orde r to avoid missing potentially suspicious activity because

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: common cash structuring techniques often involve transactions that are slightly under the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: CTR threshold.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Once established, the bank should review and test system capabilities and thresholds on a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: periodic basis .  This review should focus on specific parameter s or filter s in order  to ensure

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: that intended information is accurately captured and that the parameter or filter is appropriate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: for the bank’s particular risk profile.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Understanding the filter ing criteria of a surveillance monitoring system is critical to assessing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the effectiveness of the system .  System filtering criteria should be developed through a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: review of specific higher -risk products and services , customers and entities, and geographi es.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: System filtering criteria, including specific profiles and rules, should be based on what is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reasonable and expected for each type of account .  Monitoring accounts  purely based on

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: historical activity can be misleading if the  activity is not actually co nsistent with similar

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: types of accounts .  For example, an account  may have a historical transaction activity that is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: substantially different from what would normally be expected from that type of account  (e.g.,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: a check -cashing business that deposits large sums of currency versus withdrawing currency

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to fund the cashing of checks).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The authority to establish or change expected activity profiles should be clearly defined through policies and procedures.  Controls should ensure limited access to the monitoring systems, and changes should generally require the approval of the BSA compliance officer or senior management .  Management should document and  be able to explain filtering criteria,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: thresholds used, and how both are appropriate for the bank’ s risks.  Management should also

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: periodically review and test the filtering criteria and thresholds established to ensure that they are still effective .  In addition, the monitoring system’s programming methodology an d

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: effectiveness should be independently validated to ensure that the models are detecting potentially suspicious activity.  The independent validation should also verify the policies in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: place and that management is complying with those policies.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  67 11/17/2014  Managing A lerts

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Alert management focuses on processes used to investigate and evaluate identified unusual

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activity .  Banks should be aware of all methods of identification and should ensure that their

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious activity monitoring program includes processes to eval uate any unusual activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identified, regardless of the method of identification.  Banks should have policies, procedures, and processes in place for referring unusual activity from all areas of the bank or business lines to the personnel or department res ponsible for evaluating unusual activity .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Within those procedures, management should establish a clear and defined escalation process

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: from the point of initial detection to disposition of the investigation.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The bank should assign adequate staff to the ide ntification, evaluation, and reporting of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: potentially suspicious activities, taking into account the bank’s overall risk profile and the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: volume of transactions .  Additionally, a bank should ensure that the assigned staff possess the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: requisite experience levels and are provided with comprehensive and ongoing training to maintain their expertise .  Staff should also be provided with sufficient internal and external

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: tools to allow them to properly research activities and formulate conclusions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Internal research  tools include, but are not limited to, access to account systems and account

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: information, including CDD and EDD information.  CDD and EDD information assist banks

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: in evaluating if the unusual activity is considered suspicious .  For additional information,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: refer to the core overview section , “Customer Due Diligence ,” page  56.  External research

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: tools may include widely available Internet media search tools , as well those accessible by

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: subscription.  After thorough research and analysis, investigators should document

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: conclusions including any recommendation regarding whether or not to fil e a SAR.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Whe n multiple departments are responsible for researching unusual activities (i.e. , the BSA

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: department researches BSA -related activity and the F raud department researches fraud -

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: related activity), the lines of communication between the departments must remain open .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: This allows banks with bifurcated processes to gain efficiencies by sharing information,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reducing  redundancies, and ensuring all suspicious activity is identified, evaluated,  and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reported.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: If applicable, reviewing and understanding suspicious activity monitoring across the organizations’ affiliates, subsidiaries, and business lines may enhance a banki ng

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: organization’s ability to detect suspicious activity , and thus minimize the potential for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: financial losses, increased legal or compliance expenses, and reputational risk to the organization.  Refer to the expanded overview section, “BSA/AML Compliance P rogram

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Structure s,” page  155, for further guidance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Identifying Underlying Crime

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks are required to report suspicious activity that may involve money laundering, BSA violations, terrorist financing,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 63 and certain other crimes above prescribed dollar thresholds .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 63 If a bank knows, suspec ts, or has reason to suspect that a customer may be linked to terrorist activity against

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the United States, the bank should immediately call FinCEN’s Financial Institutions t errorist hot line toll -free

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: number  (866) 556-3974.  Similarly, if any other suspec ted violation — such as an ongoing money laundering

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  68 11/17/2014  However, banks are not obligated to investigate or confirm the underlying crime (e.g.,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: terrorist financing, money laundering, tax evasion, identity theft, and various types of fraud) .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Investig ation is the responsibility of law enforcement .  When evaluating suspicious activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and completing the SAR, banks should, to the best of their ability, identify the characteristics of the suspicious activity .  Suspicious Activity Information, Part II of t he SAR provides a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: number of categories with different types of suspicious activity .  Within each category, there

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: is the option of selecting “Other” if none of the suspicious activities apply.  However, the use of “Other” should be limited to situations tha t cannot be broadly identified within the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: categories provided.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: SAR Decision  Making

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: After thorough research and analysis has been completed, findings are typically forwarded to a final decision maker (individual or committee) .  The bank should have policies , procedures,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and processes for referring unusual activity from all business lines to the personnel or department responsible for evaluating unusual activity .  Within those procedures ,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: management should establish  a clear and defined escalation process from  the point of initial

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: detection to disposition of the investigation.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The decision maker, whether an individual or committee, should have the authority to make

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the final SAR filing decision .  Whe n the bank uses a committee, there should be a clearly

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: defined  process to resolve differences of opinion on filing decisions .  Banks should document

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: SAR decisions, including the specific reason for filing or not filing a SAR .  Thorough

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: documentation provides a record of the SAR decision- making process, including fina l

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: decisions not to file a SAR .  However, due to the variety of systems used to identify, track,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and report suspicious activity, as well as the fact that each suspicious activity reporting decision is  based on unique facts and circumstances, no single form of documentation is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: required when a bank decides not to file.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The decision to file a SAR is an inherently subjective judgment .  Examiners should focus on

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: whether the bank has an effective SAR decisi on-making process, not individual SAR

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: decisions .  Examiners may review individual SAR decisions as a means to test the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: effectiveness of the SAR monitoring, reporting, and decision- making process .  In those

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: instances where the bank has an established SAR de cision -making process, has followed

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: existing policies, procedures, and processes , and has determined not to file a SAR, the bank

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: should not be criticized for the failure to file a SAR unless the failure is significant or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: accompanied by evidence of bad fait h.65

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: SAR Filing on Continuing Activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: One purpose of filing SARs is to identify violations or potential violations of law to the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: appropriate law enforcement authorities for criminal investigation .  This objective is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: scheme — requires immediate attention, the bank should notify the appropriate federal banking and law

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: enforcement agencies.  In either case, the bank must also file a SAR.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 64 Bank Secrecy Act Advisory Grou p, “Section 4 — Tips on SAR Form Preparation & Filing,” The SAR Activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Review — Trends, Tips & Issues , Issue 10, May 2006, page 38, on the FinCEN Web site .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 65 Refer to  Appendix R  (“Interagency Enforcement Statement”)  for additional information.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  69 11/17/2014  accomplished by the filing of a SAR that identifies the activity of concern .  If this activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: continues over a period of time, such information should be made known to law enforcement

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and the federal banking agencies .  FinCEN ’s guidelines have suggest ed that banks should

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: report continuing suspi cious activity by filing a report at least every 90 calendar days .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Subsequent guidance permits banks with SAR requirements to file SARs for continuing activity after a 90 day review with the f iling deadline being 120 calendar days after the date

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of the pr eviously r elated SAR filing.  Banks may also file SARs on continuing activity earlier

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: than the 120- day deadline if the bank believes the activity warrant s earlier review by law

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: enforcement.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 66 This practice notif ies law enforcement of the continuing nature of the activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: in aggregate .  In addition, this practice remind s the bank that it should continue to review the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious activity to determine whether other actions may be appropriate, such as bank management determining that it is necessary to terminate a relationship with the customer or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: employee that is the subject of the filing.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks should be aware that law enforcement may have an interest in ensuring that certain

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: accounts remain open notwithstanding suspic ious or potential criminal activity in connection

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: with those accounts .  If a law enforcement agency requests that a bank maintain a particular

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: account, the bank should ask for a written request .  The written request should indicate that

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the agency has requ ested that the bank maintain the account and the purpose and duration of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the request .  Ultimately, the decision to maintain or close an account should be made by a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank in accordance with its own standards and guidelines.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The bank should develop policies, procedures, and processes indicating when to escalate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: issues or problems identified as the result of repeat SAR filings on accounts .  The procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: should include:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Review by senior management and legal staff (e.g., BSA compliance officer or SAR committee ).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Criteria for when analysis of the overall customer relationship is necessary.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Criteria for whe ther and, if so, when to close the account.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Criteria for when to notify law enforcement, if app ropriate .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: SAR Completion and Filing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: SAR completion and filing are a critical part of the SAR monitoring and reporting process .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Appropriate policies, procedures, and processes should be in place to ensure SAR s  are filed

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: in a timely manner, are complete and accurate, and that the narrative provides a sufficient

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: descr iption of the activity reported as well as the basis for filing .  FinCEN developed a new

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: electronic BSA Suspicious Activity Report (BSAR) that replaced FinCEN SAR -DI form TD

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: F 90-22.47.  The BSAR provides a uniform data collection format that can be used a cross

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: multiple industries.  As of April 1, 2013, the BSAR is mandatory and must be filed through

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 66 Refer to Frequently Asked Questions Regarding the FinCEN Suspicious Activity Report, Question #16 .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 67 Refer to Requests by Law Enforcement for Financial Institutions to Maintain Accounts , June 13, 2007.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  70 11/17/2014  FinCEN’s BSA E -Filing System.  The BSAR does not create or otherwise change existing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: statutory and regulatory expectations for banks.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The BSAR includes a number of additional data elements pertaining to the type of suspicious

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activity and the financial services involved .  Certain fields in the BSA R are marked as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: “critical” for technical filing purposes .  This means the BSA E -Filing System does  not accept

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: filings in which these fields are left blank.  For these items, the bank must either provide the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: requested information or check the “unknown” box that is provided with each critical field.  Banks should provide the most complete filing information available consistent with existing regulatory expectations, regardless of whether or not the individual fields are deemed critical for technical filing purposes.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks should report the information that they know, or that otherwise arises, as part of their case r eviews .  Other than the critical fields, the addition of the new and expanded data

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: elements does not create an expectation that banks will revise internal programs, or develop new programs, to capture information t hat reflects the expanded lists .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 69  Refer t o Appendix T

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: for additional information on filing through the BSA E -Filing System.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Timing of a SAR Filing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The SAR rules require that a SAR be electronically filed through the BSA E -Filing System

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: no later than 30 calendar days from the date of the initial  detection of facts that may

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: constitute a basis for filing a SAR .  If no s uspect can be  identified , the time period for filing a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: SAR is extended to 60 days .  Organizations may need to review transaction or account

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activity for a customer to determine whether to file a SAR .  The need for a review of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customer activity or transactions does not necessarily indicate a need to file a SAR .  The time

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: period for filing a SAR starts when the organization, during its review or because of other factors, knows or has reason to suspect that the activity or transactions under review meet

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: one or more of the definitions of suspicious activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The phrase “initial detection” should not be interpreted as meaning the moment a transaction

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: is highlighted for review .  There are a variety of legitimate transactions that could raise a red

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: flag simply because they are inconsistent with an accountholder’s normal account activity .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: For example, a real estate investment (purchase or sale), the receipt of an inheritance, or a gift, may cause an account to have a significant credit or debit that would be inconsistent with typical account activity .  The bank’s automated account monitoring system or initial

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: discovery of information, such as system -generated reports, may flag the transaction;

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: however, this should not be considered initial detection of potential suspicious activity .  The

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 30-day (or 60 -day) period does not begin until an appropriate review is conducted and a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 68 Refer to Filing FinCEN’s new Currency Transaction Report and Suspicious Activity Report , FIN -2012- G002,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 69 Id.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 70 Bank Secrecy Act Advisory Group, “Section 5 — Issues and Guidance,” The SAR Activity Review —  Trends,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Tips & Issues , Issue 1, October 2000,  page 27.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Suspicious Activity Reporting — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  71 11/17/2014  determination is made that the transaction under review is “suspic ious” within the meaning

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of the SAR regulation.71

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Whenever possible, an expeditious review of the transaction or the account is recommended

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and can be of significant assistance to law enforcement .  In any event, the review should be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: completed in a reasonabl e period of time .  What constitutes a “reasonable period of time”

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: varies according to the facts and circumstances of the particular matter being reviewed and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the effectiveness of the SAR monitoring, reporting, and decision- making process of each

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank.  The  key factor is that a bank has established adequate procedures for reviewing and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assessing facts and circumstances identified as potentially suspicious, and that those

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: procedures are documented and followed.72

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: For situations requiring immediate attention, i n addition to filing a timely SAR , a bank must

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: immediately notify, by telephone, an “ appropriate law enforcement authority ” and, as
