content: blocking or rejecting the transaction, as appropriate .  Refer to the core overview section,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: “Office of Foreign Asset Control,” page  142, for additional guidance .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: In guidance issued on March 10, 2009, OFAC authorized institutions in the United States when they are acting as an ODFI/ Gateway  for inbound IAT debits to reject transactions that

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: appear to involve blockable property or property interests.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 217 The guidance further stated that

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to the extent that an ODFI/Gateway  screens inbound IAT debits for possible OFAC

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: violations prior t o execution and in the course of such screening discovers a potential OFAC

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: violation, the suspect transaction is to be removed from the batch for further investigation.  If

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the ODFI/ Gateway  determines that the transaction does appear to violate OFAC regula tions,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the ODFI/ Gateway  should refuse to process the transfer .  The procedure applies to

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transactions that would normally be blocked as well as to transactions that would normally be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: rejected for OFAC purposes based on the information in the payments.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Addi tional information on the types of retail payment systems (ACH payment systems) is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: available in the FFIEC  Information Technology Examination Handbook ’s Retail Payment

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Systems  booklet .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 217 Refer  to OFAC letter (March 10, 2009 ).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Automated Clearing House Transactions — Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  225 11/17/2014  Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Automated Clearing House Transactions

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the adequacy of the bank ’s systems to manage the risks associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: automated clearing house (ACH) and international ACH transactions  (IAT) and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: management ’s ability to implement effective monitoring and reporting systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 1. Review the policies, procedures, and processes related to ACH transactions , including

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: IATs .  Evaluate the adequacy of the policies , procedures, and processes given the bank’ s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: ACH transactions , including IATs, and the risks they present .  Assess whether the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: controls are adequate to reasonably protect the bank from money laundering and terrorist

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: financing.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 2. From  review of MIS and int ernal risk rating factors, determine whether the bank

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: effectively identifies and monitors higher -risk customers using ACH transactions ,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: including IATs .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 3. Evaluate the bank ’s risks related to ACH transactions , including IATs, by analyzing the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: frequency and  dollar volume and types of ACH transactions  in relation to the bank’ s size,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: its location, the nature of its customer account relationships , and the location of the origin

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: or destination of IATs relative to the bank’s location.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 4. Determine whether the ban k’s system for monitoring customers, including third -party

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: service providers (TPSP), using ACH transactions and IATs for suspicious activities, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: for reporting of suspicious activities, is adequate given the bank’ s size, complexity,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: location, and types of customer relationships .  Determine whether internal control

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: systems include:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Identifying customers with frequent and large ACH transactions  or IATs .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Monitoring ACH detail activity when the batch -processed transactions are separated

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: for other purposes (e .g., processing errors).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • As appropriate, identifying and applying  increased due diligence to higher -risk

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customers who originate  or receive IATs , particularly when a party to the transaction

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: is located in a higher -risk geographic location.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Using m ethods to track, review, and investigate customer complaints or unauthorized

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: returns regarding possible fraudulent or duplicate ACH transactions , including IATs .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 5. If appropriate, refer to the core examination procedures, “Office of Foreign Assets Control,” page 152, for guidance .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Transaction Testing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 6. On the basis of the bank ’s risk assessment of customers with ACH transactions as well as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: prior examination and audit reports, select a sample of higher -risk customers, including

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: TPSPs, with ACH transactions  or IATs , which may include the following:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Automated Clearing House Transactions — Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  226 11/17/2014  • Customers initiating ACH transactions , including IATs, from the Internet or via

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: telephone, particularly from an account  opened on the Internet or via the telephone

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: without face -to-face interaction.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Customers whose business  or occupation does not warrant the volume or nature of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: ACH or IAT activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Customers who have been involved in the origination or receipt of duplicate or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: fraudulent ACH transactions  or IATs .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Customers or originators (clients of customers) that are generating a high rate or high volume of invalid account returns, consumer unauthorized returns, or other

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: unauthorized transactions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 7. From the sample selected, analyze ACH transactions , including IATs, to determine

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: whether the amounts, frequency, and jurisdictions of origin or destination are consistent

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: with the nature of the business or occupation of the customer .  A review of the account

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: opening documentation, including CIP documentation, may be necessary in making these

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: determinations .  Identify any suspicious or unusual activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 8. On the basis of examination procedures completed, including transaction testing, form a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: conclusion about the adequacy of policies, procedures, and processes associat ed with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: ACH transactions  and IATs .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  227 11/17/2014  Prepaid Access - Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the adequacy of the bank’s systems to manage the risks associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: prepaid access products, and m anagement’s ability to implement effective monitoring and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reporting systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid access is defined as acc ess to funds or the value of funds that have been paid in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: advance and can be retrieved or transferred at some point in the future through an electr onic

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: device or vehicle, such as a card, code, electronic serial number, mobile identification

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: number or personal identification number.218

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks often rely on multiple third parties to accomplish the design, implementation, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: maintenance of their prepaid access programs.  These third parties may include program

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: managers, distributors, marketers, merchants, and processors.  Some banks that offer prepaid access products do so as the issuing bank.  In addition to issuing prepaid access , banks may

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: participate i n other aspects of a prepaid program such as marketing and distributing products

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: issued by a nother financial institution.   FinCEN regulations define certain non- bank

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: providers and sellers of prepaid access as money services businesses ( MSBs) .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid access can be issued in an electronic or physical form  and linked to funds held in a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: pooled account .  Consumers use both electronic and physical prepaid products to access

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: funds held by banks in pooled accounts that are linked to subaccounts.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The growth of  prepaid access as a financial tool continues to flourish.  While prepaid cards

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: are the most well -known and popular products used by consumers at this time, prepaid access

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: products are continuing to evolve.  This section is intended to address prepaid card relationships as well as other type s of prepaid access.  Guidance on risk factors and risk

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: mitigation for prepaid cards is based on current practice and is not intended to exclude other

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: types of prepaid access.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Cards

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid access can cover a var iety of products, functionalities, and technologies.  Physical

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: access, issued in the form of prepaid cards, is currently the most popular form and is widely

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: used for payments by governments, businesses and consumers.  Most payment networks require that the ir branded prepaid cards be issued by a bank that is a member of that payment

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: network.  Prepaid cards operate within either an “open” or “closed” loop system.  Open  loop

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: prepaid cards can be used for purchases at any merchant that accepts cards issued for use on the payment network associated with the card and  to access cash at any automated teller

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: machine (ATM) that connects to the affiliated ATM network.  Examples of open loop

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: prepaid cards include payroll cards , general purpose reloadable (GPR) cards, and certain gift

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: cards.  Some prepaid cards may be reloaded, allowing the cardholder or other person (such as an employer) to add value.  Closed loop prepaid cards generally can only be used to buy

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: goods or service s from the merchant issuing the card or a select group of merchants or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: service providers that participate in a specific network.  Examples of closed  loop prepaid

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: cards  include merchant -specific retail gift cards, mall cards, and mass transit system cards.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  228 11/17/2014  Closed loop prepaid cards generally do not allow for cash access, although they can often be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: resold through third -party  Web sites in exchange for other closed loop cards or payment via

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: check, ACH or other method.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid cards are highly flexible and can be customized to meet the needs of the specific

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: program.  Some prepaid card programs are designed for specific limited -use purposes, such

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: as flexible spending account (FSA) or health savings account ( HSA ) card s that can be used to

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: purchase specific health -related  services .  Some prepaid card programs are used by state and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: federal government agencies to disburse government benefits ( e.g., disability,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: unemployment, etc.) or provide income tax refunds, or by employers to deliver wage and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: salary payments .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Like debit cards, prepaid cards provide a compact and transportable way to maintain and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: access funds.  Consumers use prepaid cards in a variety of ways, such as purchasing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: products, making transfers to other cardholders within the prepaid program, and pa ying bills .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: They also offer individuals an alternative to cash and money orders.  As an alternate method

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of cross -border funds transmittal, a small number of prepaid card programs may issue

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: multiple cards per account, so that persons in another country or j urisdiction can access the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: funds loaded by the original cardholder via ATM withdrawals of cash or merchant purchases.  For such programs, risk -based customer due diligence should be conducted on the original

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: cardholder and transactions should be subjected to risk -based monitoring.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access Participants

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid access programs often rely on multiple third parties to accomplish the design, implementation, and maintenance of their programs.  Within a prepaid access program, these

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: parties are known by the following terms:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Program Manager.  Runs the program’s day -to-day operations.  This entity may or may

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: not also be the entity that creates the program and designs the features and characteristics

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of the prepaid product.  May be a provider of prepaid access  (Money Services Business

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: (MSB) ) under FinCEN’s rule.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Network.  Any of the payment networks that clear , settle , and process  transactions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Distributor.  An organization tha t markets and distributes prepaid products .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Provider of Prepaid Access.  A participant within a prepaid program that agrees to serve

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: as the principal conduit for access to information from its fellow program participants.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The provider must register with FinCEN as an MSB and identify each prepaid program for which it is the provi der of prepaid access.  As an MSB, providers of prepaid access

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: are subject to certain BSA/AML responsibilities.  A bank that serves as a provider of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: prepaid access has no requirement to register with FinCEN.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Payment Processor.  The entity that tracks and m anages transactions and may be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: responsible for account set -up and activation; adding value to products; and fraud control

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and reporting.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  229 11/17/2014  • Issuing Bank.  A bank that offers network branded prepaid products to consumers and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: may serve as the holder of funds that have been prepaid and are awaiting instructions to

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: be disbursed.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Seller or Retailer. A convenience store, drugstore, supermarket, or location where a consumer can buy a prepaid product .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Contractual Agreements

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Each relationship that a U.S. bank has with another financial institution or third party as part

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of a prepaid access program should be governed by an agreement or a contract describing each party’s responsibilities and other relationship details, such as the products and services provided.  The agre ement or contract should also consider each party’s BSA/AML and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: OFAC compliance requirements, customer base, due diligence procedures, and any payment network obligations.  The issuing bank maintains ultimate responsibility for BSA/AML

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: compliance whether o r not a contractual agreement has been established.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Risk Factors

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: As with other payment instruments, money laundering, terrorist financing, and other criminal

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activity may occur through prepaid access and prepaid card programs if effective controls are

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: not in place.  For example, law enforcement investigations h ave found that some prepaid

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: holders have used false identification and funded their initial loads with stolen credit cards ,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: or have purchased multiple prepaid cards under aliases.  In the placement phase of money laundering, because many domestic and offshore banks offer prepaid access products or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: services with currency access through ATMs internationally, criminals may load cash from

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: illicit sources onto prepaid  access products and send them to accom plices inside or outside

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the United States .  Generally, domestically issued prepaid cards  can only be loaded in the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: United States .  Investigations have disclosed that both open and closed loop prepaid cards

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: have been used in conjunction with, or as a repla cement to, bulk cash smuggling.  Although

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: prepaid access is increasingly regulated and is issued by highly regulated banks , some third

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: parties involved in marketing or distributing prepaid access  programs may or may not be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: subject to regulatory requirements, oversight, and supervision.  In addition, these

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: requirements may vary by party.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid access  programs are extremely diverse in the range of products and services offered

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and the customer bas es they serve.  In evaluating the risk profile of a prepaid access  program,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: banks should consider the program’s specific features and functionalities.  H igher potential

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: money laundering risk associated with prepaid access would result if the holder  is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: anon ymous, or if the holder or purchaser provides  fictitious holder /purchaser  information .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Higher risk is also associated with cash access (especially internationally), and the volume

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and velocity of funds that can be loaded or transacted.  Other risk factors  include type and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: frequency of loads and transactions, geographic location where the transaction activity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: occurs , the relationships between the bank and parties associated with the program, value

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: limits, distribution channels, and the nature of funding sources.   Transactions using prepaid

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: access may pose the following unique risks to the bank:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Funds may be transferred to or from an unknown third party.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  230 11/17/2014  • Verification  of cardhol der identity may be done entirely remotely, relying on third -party

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: program managers , processors or distributors.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • As with other modes of electronic payments ( e.g., ACH, wire transfer, credit and debit

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: cards), holders may be able to use prepaid access products internationally, thus avoiding

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: border restrictions and reporting requirements ap plicable to cash and monetary

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: instruments.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Transactions may be credited or debited to the user’s payment product immediately,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: although there may be a lag in delivery of funds to the issuing bank, creating a load

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: timing risk for the bank (also referred to a s a “funds in flight” risk) .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Specific holder activity may be difficult to determine by reviewing activity through a pooled account.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Data in underlying pooled accounts may be held or managed by third parties, separate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: from the issuing bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Marketing of payment products, customer service, and onboarding of new customers (both consumer and business customers) may be handled primarily by third parties

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: separate from the issuing bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The customer may perceive the transactions as less transparent.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Source of payroll funding may come through an intermediary bank and may not be transparent.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Risk Mitigation

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks that offer prepaid access  or otherwise participate in prepaid access  programs should

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: have policies, procedures, and processes sufficient to manage the re lated BSA/AML risks  as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: required under the BSA and implementing regulations, as well as under payment network

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: rules .  Guidance provided by the Network Branded Prepaid Card Association is an additional

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: resource for banks that provide prepaid card services .220

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: BSA/AML ri sk mitigation is an important factor  for prepaid access programs , involving

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: several key components:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Conducting appropriate d ue diligence on any third -party  service provider .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Conducting a r isk assessment of the prepaid access product itself including product

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: features and how it is distri buted and loaded.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Monitoring transactions conducted or attempted by, at or through the bank for unusual or suspicious activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Product features and limits on usage.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 220 Refer to “ Recommended Practices for Anti -Money Laundering Compliance for U.S. -Based Prepaid Card

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Programs ,” February 28, 2008.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  231 11/17/2014  Third -Party Service Providers

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: A bank’s C ustomer Due Diligence (C DD) program should provide for a risk assessment of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: all third parties involved in offering, managing, distributing, processing, or otherwise

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: implementing the prepaid access  program, considering all relevant factors, including, as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: appropriate:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • A review of such party’ s BSA/AM L compliance program.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Systems integrity and BSA/AML monitoring capabilities.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The policies on outsourcing should include processes for (1) documenting in writing the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: roles and responsibilities of the parties, (2) ma intaining the confidentiality of customer

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: information, and (3) maintaining the necessary access to information.  The policies

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: should include the right to audit the third party to monitor its performance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The BSA/AML and OFAC obligations of third parties.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • On-site audits .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Corporate documentation, licenses, references (including independent reporting services),

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and, if appropriate, documentation on principal owners.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • An understanding of the third party’s overall compliance culture.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Product Features and Distribution

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Product features can provide important mitigation to the BSA/AML risks inherent in prepaid

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: access and prepaid card relationships and transactions and may include:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Limits or prohibitions on cash loads, access, or redemption, particularly where holder

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: information is not on file .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Limits or prohibitions on amounts of loads and number of loads/reloads within a specific time frame ( load velocity limits ).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Controls on the number of cards purchased by one individual  or the number of cards that

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: can access the s ame card account .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Controls on the ability to transfer or co- mingle funds.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Maximum dollar thresholds on ATM withdrawals and on the number of withdrawals within a specific time frame ( ATM velocity limits ).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Maximum dollar thresholds on Point of Sale (POS) tra nsactions for individual s and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transactions within a preset time period (i.e., da ily or monthly); and on the number of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: withdrawals within a specific time frame (POS velocity limits).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Limits or prohibitions on certain usage (e.g., merchant type) and on geogr aphic usage,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: such as outside the United States.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The ability to reverse transactions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  232 11/17/2014  • Limits on aggregate card values.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Other features that mitigate risks in this area include:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The identity and location of all third parties involved in selling or distributing the prepaid

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: access program, including any subagents.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The type, purpose, and anticipated activity of the prepaid access program.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Customers/ Prepaid Users

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Customer due diligence regardin g the purchaser and/or the user(s) of the prepaid product can

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: also be i mportant BSA/AML risk mitigant and may include:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Whether the source of funds is known and trusted (such as corporate or government

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: loads, vs. loads by individuals).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The nature of the third parties’ businesses and the markets and customer bases served.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The information collected to identify and verify the holders ’ identity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The nature and duration of the bank’s relationship with third parties who are the source of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: funds in the prepaid access program.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The company requesting payroll funding and the source of pa yroll funding.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The ability to monitor and tra ck loads, transactions and velocity .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: As part of their system of internal controls, banks should establish a means for monitoring, identi fying, and reporting suspicious activity related to prepaid access  programs .  This

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reporting obligation extends to all transactions by, at, or through the bank, including those in an aggregated form.  Banks may need to establish protocols to regularly obtain transaction information from processors or other third parties.  Monitor ing systems should have the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: ability to identify foreign activity, bulk purchases made by one individual, and multiple purchases made by related parties.  In addition, procedures should include monitoring for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: unusual activity patterns, such as :

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • cash loads f ollowed immediately by withdrawals of the full amount from another

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: location , or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • multiple unrelated funds transfers onto the prepaid access product, such as in tax refund

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: fraud situations where multiple tax refunds are loaded onto one card.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Various manageme nt information system reports ( MIS) may be useful for detecting unusual

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activity on higher -risk accounts .  Those reports  include ATM activity reports (focusing on

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: foreign transactions), funds transfer reports, new account activity reports, change of Internet address reports, Internet Protocol (IP) address reports, and reports to identify related or linked accounts (e.g., common addresses, phone numbers, e -mail addresses, and taxpayer

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identification numbers).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access –  Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  233 11/17/2014  Examination  Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the adequacy of the bank’s systems to manage the risks associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: prepaid access, and management’s ability to implement effective monitoring and reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 1. Review the policies, procedures, and processes related to prepaid access.  Evaluate the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: risks pos ed by the prepaid access products offered, and the adequacy of the policies,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: procedures, and processes given  the risks such prepaid access products present.  Assess whether the controls are adequate to reasonably protect the bank from money laundering

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and terrorist financing.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 2. Review the due diligence undertaken by the bank regarding third -party  service providers

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: such as program managers, processors, marketer s, merchants and distributors.  Assess

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: whether existing onboarding and ongoing oversight programs are reasonably satisfactory to protect the bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 3. From  a review of MIS and internal risk rating factors, determine whether the bank

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: effectively identifies and monitors higher -risk prepaid access transactions, such as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transactions involving unknown sources of funds (as opposed to funds received from a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: long-term commercial customer or federal, state or local government entity) as well as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transactions involving int ernational cash access/ATM transactions (as opposed to

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: domestic merchandise -only transactions) .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 4. Determine whether the bank’s prepaid access program is governed by an agreement or a contract describing each party’s responsibilities and other relationship de tails, such as the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: products and services provided.  At a minimum, the contract should consider each

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: party’s:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • BSA/AML and OFAC compliance requirements;

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • customer base;

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • due diligence procedures; and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • network obligations.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 5. Determine whether the bank’s system for monitoring prepaid access  transactions for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious activities, and for reporting suspicious activities, is adequate given the bank’s size, complexity, location, customer profile, and types of prepaid access products offered .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 6. If appropriate, refer  to the examination procedures, “Office of Foreign Assets Control,”

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: page  152; “Third Party Payment Processors,” page  239; and “Nonb ank Financial

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Institutions,” page  307, for guidance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Prepaid Access –  Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  234 11/17/2014  Transaction Testing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 7. On the basis of the bank’s risk assessment of its  prepaid access  activities, as well as prior

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: examination and audit reports, select a sample of prepaid access  transactions.  From the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: sample selected perform the following examination procedures:   Review the prepaid

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: access product configuration(s), including features, how it is distributed, source of funds,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and what BSA/AM L risk mitigants apply.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Review the prepaid access product configuration(s), including features, how it is distributed, source of funds, and what BSA/AML risk mitigants apply.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Review account opening documentation, including CIP, ongoing CDD, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transaction history.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Compare expected activity with actual activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Determine whether the activity is consistent with the nature of the pre paid access

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: product, known source s of funds, and knowledge of the user ’s identity .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Identify any unusual or suspicious activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 8. On the basis of examination procedures completed, including transaction testing, form a conclusion about the adequacy of poli cies, procedures, and processes associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: prepaid access  relationships.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Third -Party Payment Processors — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  235 11/17/2014  Third- Party Payment Processors — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the adequacy of the bank ’s systems to manage the risks associated with its

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: relationships with third -party payment processors, and management ’s ability to implement

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: effective monitoring and reporting systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Nonbank or third -party payment processors (processors) are bank customers that provide

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: payment -processing services  to merchants and other business entities .  Traditionally,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: processors contracted primarily with retailers that had physical locations in order to process

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the retailers’ transactions .  These merchant transactions primarily included credit card

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: payments but also covered automated clearing house (ACH) transactions ,221 remotely created

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: checks  (RCC),222 and debit and prepaid  cards transactions .  With the expansion of the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Internet, retail borders have been eliminated .  Processors now provide services to a variety of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: merchant accounts, including conventional retail and Internet -based establishments, prepaid

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: travel, telemarketers, and Internet gaming enterprises.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Third -party payment processors often use their commercial bank accounts to conduct

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: payment processing for their merchant clients .  For example, the processor may deposit into

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: its account RCCs generated on behalf of a merchant client, or process ACH transactions  on

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: behalf of a merchant client .  In either case, the bank does not have a direct relationship with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the merchant .  The increased use of RCCs by processor customers also raises the risk of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: fraudulent payments being processed through the processor’s bank account .  The Federal

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) , Office of the Comptroller of the Currency  (OCC ),

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and Financial Crimes Enforcement Network  (FinCEN) have issued guidance regarding the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: risks, including the BSA/AML risks, associated with banking third- party processors.223

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Risk Factors

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Processors generally are not subject to BSA/AML regulatory requirement s.  As a result,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: some processors may be vulnerable to money laundering, identity theft, fraud schemes , or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: other illicit transactions , including those  prohibited by OFAC .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The bank’s BSA/AML risks when dealing with a processor account are similar to risks fr om

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: other activities in which the bank’s customer conducts transactions through the bank on

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 221 NACHA – The Electronic Payments Association ( NACHA) is the administrator of the Automated Clearing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: House (ACH) Network. The ACH Network is governed by the NACHA Operating Rules, which provides the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: legal foundation for the exchange of ACH and IAT payments . The NACHA Web site  includes additional

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: information about the ACH payment system.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 222 A remotely created check (sometimes called a “demand draft”) is a check that is not created by the paying

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank (often created by a payee or its service provider), drawn on a customer’s bank account.  The check often is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: authorized by the customer remotely,  by telephone or online, and, therefore, does not bear the customer’s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: handwritten signature.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 223 FDIC Clarifying Supervisory Approach to Institutions Establishing Account Relationships with Third- Party

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Payment Processors, FDIC FIL -41-2014, July 28, 2014; Payment Processor Relationships Revised Guidance ,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FDIC FIL -3-2012, January 31, 2012;  Risk Management Guidance: Payment Processors , OCC Bulletin 2008-

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 12, April 24, 2008; Risk Management Guidance: Third Party Relationships , OCC Bulletin 2013- 29, October

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 30, 2013; and Risk Associated with Third -Party Payment Processors, FinCEN Advisory FIN -2012- A010,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: October 22, 2012.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Third -Party Payment Processors — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  236 11/17/2014  behalf of the customer’s clients .  When the bank is unable to identify and understand the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: nature and source of the transactions processed through an account, the ris ks to the bank and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the likelihood of suspicious activity can increase .  If a bank has not implemented an adequate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: processor -approval program that goes beyond credit risk management, it could be vulnerable

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to processing illicit or OFAC -sanctioned transactio ns.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Whil e payment processors generally a ffect legitimate payment transactions for reputable

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: merchants, the risk profile of such entities can vary significantly depending on the make -up

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of their customer base.  Banks with third -party  payment processor customers should be aware

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of the heightened risk of returns and use of services by higher -risk merchants .  Some higher -

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: risk merchants routinely use third parties to process their transactions because they do not

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: have a direct bank relati onship.  Payment processors pose greater money laundering and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: fraud risk if they do not have an effective means of verifying their merchant clients’

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identities and business practices .  Risks are heightened when the processor does not perform

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: adequate due d iligence on the merchants for which they are originating payments.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Risk Mitigation

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks offering account services to processors should develop and maintain adequate policies, procedures, and processes to address risks related to these relationships .  At a  minimum,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: these policies should authenticate the processor’s business operations and assess their risk level .  A bank may assess the risks associated with payment processors  by considering  the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: following:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Implementing a policy that requires an initial backg round check of the processor (using ,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: for example, the F ederal T rade C ommission  Web site, Better Business Bureau,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Nationwide M ulti-State Licensing System & Registry (NMLS), NACHA, state

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: incorporation departments, Internet searches, and other investigative processes) , its

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: principal owners, and of the processor’s  underlying merchants , on a risk- adjusted basis in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: order to verify their creditworthiness and general business practices.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Reviewing the processor’s promotional materials, including its W eb site, to det ermine the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: target clientele .  A bank may develop policies, procedures, and processes that restrict the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: types of entities for which it allow s processing services .  These restrictions should be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: clearly communicated to the  processor at account opening .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Determining whether the processor re -sells its services to a third party who may be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: referred to as an “agent or provider of Independent Sales Organization (ISO)

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: opportunities” or “gateway” arrangements.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Reviewing the processor’s policies, procedures, and processes to determine the adequacy

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of its due diligence standards for new merchants.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 224 Gateway arrangements are similar to an Internet service provider with excess computer storage capacity that

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: sells its capacity to a third party that would then distribute computer services to various other individuals

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: unknown to the provider.  The third party would be making decisions about who would be receiving the service,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: although the provider would be providing the ultimate storage capacity.  Thus, the provider bears all of the risks

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: while receiving a smaller profit.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Third -Party Payment Processors — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  237 11/17/2014  • Requiring the processor to identify its major customers by providing information such as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the merchant’s name, princip al business activity, geographic location, and transa ction

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: volume .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Verifying directly, or through the processor, that the merchant is operating a legitimate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: business by comparing the merchant’s identifying information against public record

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: databases, and fraud and bank check databases.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Reviewing corporate documentation including independent reporting services and, if

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: applicable, documentation on principal owners.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Visiting the processor’s business operations center.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Reviewing appropriate databases to ensure that the processor and its principal owners and opera tors have not been subject to law enforcement actions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks that provide account services  to third -party payment processors  should monitor their

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: processor relationships for any significant changes in the processor ’s business strategies that

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: may affect their risk profile .  Banks should periodically re -verify and update the processors’

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: profiles to ensure the risk assessment is appropriate.  Banks should ensure that their contractual agreements with payment processors provide them with access to necessary information in a timely manner.  Banks should periodically audit their third -party payment

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: processing relationships; including reviewing  merchant client lists and confirming that the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: processor is fulfilling contractual obligations to verify the legitimacy of its merchant clients

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and their business practices.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: In addition to adequate and effective account opening and due diligence procedures for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: processor accounts, management should monitor these relationships for unusual and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious activities .  To effectively monitor these accounts, the bank should have an

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: understanding of the following processor information:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Merchant base.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Merchant activities.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Average dollar volume and number of transactions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • “Swiping” versus “keying” volume for credit card transactions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Charge -back history, including rates of return for ACH debit transactions and RCCs .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Consumer complaints or other documentation that suggest a payment processor’s merchant clients are inappropriately obtaining personal account information and using it

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to create unauthorized RCCs or ACH debits.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: With respect to account monitoring, a bank should thoroughly investigate high levels of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: returns and should not accept high levels of returns on the basis that the processor has provided collateral or other security to the bank .  High levels of RCCs or ACH debits

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: returned for insufficient funds or as unauthorized can be an indication of fraud or suspicious activity.  Therefore, return rate monitoring should not be limited to only unauthorized transactions, but include re turns for other reasons that may warrant further review, such as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: unusually high rates of return for insufficient funds or other administrative reasons.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Third -Party Payment Processors — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  238 11/17/2014  Transactions should be m onitored for patterns that may be indicative of attempts to evade

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: NACHA limitations on returned e ntries.  For example, resubmitting a transaction under a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: different name or for slightly modified dollar amounts can be an attempt to circumvent these

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: limitations  and are violations of the NACHA Rules. 225

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: A bank should implement appr opriate policies, procedures, and processes that address

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: compliance and fraud risks .  Policies and procedures should outl ine the bank’s thresholds for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: returns and establish processes to mitiga te risk from payment processors, as well as possible

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: actions tha t can be taken against the payment processors that exceed these standards.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: If the bank determines a SAR is warranted, FinCEN has requested banks check the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: appropriate box on the SAR report  to indicate the type of suspicious activity, and include the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: term “payment processor ,” in both the narrative and the subject occupation portions of the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: SAR.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 225 Refer to NACHA Operating Rules .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Third -Party Payment Processors — Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  239 11/17/2014  Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Third -Party Payment Processors

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the adequacy of the bank ’s systems to  manage the risks associated with its

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: relationships with third -party payment processors, and management ’s ability to implement

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: effective monitoring and reporting systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 1. Review the policies, procedures, and processes related to third- party payment proc essors

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: (processors).  Evaluate the adequacy of the policies, procedures, and processes given the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank’ s processor activities and the risks they present .  Assess whether the  controls are

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: adequate to reasonably protect the bank from money laundering and terr orist financing.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 2. From  a review of MIS and internal risk rating factors, determine whether the bank

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: effectively identifies and monitors processor relationships, particularly those that pose a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: higher  risk for money laundering.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 3. Determine whether the ban k’s system for monitoring processor accounts for suspicious

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activities, and for reporting suspicious activities, is adequate given the bank’ s size,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: complexity, location, and types of customer relationships.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 4. If appropriate, refer to the core examination procedures, “Office of Foreign Assets Control,” page 152, for guidance .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Transaction Testing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 5. On the basis of the bank ’s risk assessment of its processor activities, as well as prior

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
