name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: management, bill pa ying, mail forwarding, and maintenance of a residence) .  Private banking

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: has become an increasingly important business line for large and diverse banking

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: organizations and a source of enhanced fee income.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: U.S. banks may manage private banking relationships  for both domestic and international

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customers .  Typically, thresholds of private banking service are based on the amount of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assets under management and on the need for specific products or services (e.g., real estate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: management, closely held company overs ight, money management) .  The fees charged are

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: ordinarily based on asset thresholds and the use of specific products and services.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Private banking arrangements are typically structured to have a central point of contact  (i.e.,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: relationship manager) that ac ts as a liaison between the client and the bank and facilitates the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: client ’s use of the bank’ s financial services and products .  Appendix N ( “Private Banking —

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Common Structure ”) provides an example of a typical private banking structure and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: illustrates th e relationship between the client and the relationship manager .  Typical products

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and services offered in a private banking relationship include:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Cash management (e.g., checking accounts, overdraft privileges, cash sweeps, and bill -

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: paying services).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Funds transfer s.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Asset management (e.g., trust, investment advisory, investment management, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: custodial and brokerage services).246

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • The facilitation of shell companies and offshore entities (e.g., Pr ivate Investment

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Companies (PIC ), international business corpor ations (IBC ), and trusts).247

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Lending services (e.g., mortgage loans, credit cards, personal loans, and letters of credit).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Financial planning services including tax and estate planning.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Custody services.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Other services as requested (e.g., mail services).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 246 For additional guidance, refer to the expanded overview and examination procedures, “Trust and Asset

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Management Services,” page 280 and 284, respectively.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 247 For additional guidance, refer to the expanded overview and examination procedures, “Business Enti ties

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: (Domestic and Foreign),” pages 314 and 320, respectively.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Private Banking — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  274 11/17/2014  Privacy and confidentiality are important elements of private banking relationships .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Although customers may choose private banking services simply to manage their assets, they

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: may also seek a confidential, safe, and legal haven for their capital .  When acti ng as a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: fiduciary, banks have statutory, contractual, and ethical obligations to uphold.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Risk Factors

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Private banking services can be vulnerable to money laundering schemes, and past money laundering prosecutions have demonstrated that vulnerability .  The 1999 Permanent

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Subcommittee on Investigations ’ Report  “Private Banking and Money Laundering: A Case

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Study of Opportunities and Vulnerabilities ”

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 248 outlined, in part, the following vulnerabilities

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to money laundering:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Private bankers as client advocates.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Powe rful clients including politically exposed persons  (PEPs) , industrialists, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: entertainers.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Culture of confidentiality and the use of secrecy jurisdictions or shell companies.249

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Private banking culture of lax internal controls.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Competitive nature of the business.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Significant profit potential for the bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Risk Mitigation

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Effective policies, procedures, and processes  can help protect banks from becoming conduits

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: for or victims of money laundering, terrorist financing, and other financial crimes that are perpetrated through private banking relationships .  Additional information relating to risk

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assessments and due diligence is contained in the core overview section , “Private Banking

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Due Diligence Program (Non -U.S. Persons) ,” page 125.  Ultimately, illicit activities through

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the private banking unit could result in significant financial costs and reputational risk to the bank.  Financial impacts could include regulatory sanctions and fines, litigation expenses, the loss of business, reduced liquidity, asset seizures and freezes, loan losses, and remediation

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: expenses.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Customer Risk Assessment

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks should assess the risks its private banking activities pose on the basis of the scope of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: operations and the complexity of the bank’ s customer relationships .  Manage ment should

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: establish a risk profile for each customer to be used in prioritizing oversight resources and for ongoing monitoring of relationship activities .  The following factors should be considered

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: when identifying risk characteristics of private bankin g customers:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 248 Refer to U.S. Senate, Committee on Governmental Affairs, Private Banking and Money Laundering: A Case

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Study of Opportunities and Vulnerabilities

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: (frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgibin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=106_senate_hearings&docid=f:61699.pdf ).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 249 Refer to the expanded overview section, “Business Entitie s (Domestic and Foreign),” page 314, for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: additional guidance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Private Banking — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  275 11/17/2014  • Nature of the customer’s wealth  and the customer’ s business.  The source of the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customer ’s wealth, the nature of the customer ’s business, and the extent to which the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customer ’s business history presents an increased risk for money laundering a nd terrorist

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: financing .  This factor should be considered for private banking accounts opened for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: PEPs.250

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Purpose and anticipated activity .  The size, purpose, types of accounts, products, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: services involved in the relationship, and the anticipated activity of the account.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Relationship .  The nature and duration of the bank’ s relationship (including relationships

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: with affiliates) with the private banking customer.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Customer ’s corporate structure.  Type of corporate structure (e.g., IBCs, shell

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: companies (domestic or foreign), or PICs).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Geographic l ocation and jurisdiction .  The geographic location of the private banking

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customer ’s domicile and business (domestic or foreign) .  The review should consider the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: extent to which the relevant jurisdiction is internationally recognized as presenting a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: greater risk for money laundering or, conversely, is considered to have robust AML

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: standards.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Public information .  Information known or reasonably available to the bank about the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: private banking customer .  The scope and depth of this review should depend on the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: nature of this relationship and the risks involved.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Customer Due Diligence

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: CDD is essential when establishing any customer relationship and it is critical for private

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: banking clients.251 Banks should take reasonable steps to establish the identity of their private

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: banking clients and, as appropriate, the beneficial owners of accounts .252  Adequate due

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: diligence should vary based on the risk factors identified previously .  Policies, procedures,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and processes  should define acceptable CDD for different types of products (e.g., PICs),

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: services, and accountholders .  As due diligence is an ongoing process, a bank should take

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: measures to ensure account profiles are current and monitoring should be risk- based .  Bank s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: should consider whether risk profiles should be adjusted or suspicious activity reported when

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the activity is inconsistent with the profile.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: For purposes of the CIP, the bank is not required to search the private banking account to

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: verify the identities of beneficiaries, but instead is only required to verify the identity of the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 250 Refer to the core overview section, “Private Banking Due Diligence Program (Non -U.S. Persons),” page

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 125, and to the expanded overview section, “Pol itically Exposed Persons,” page 290, for additional guidance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 251 Due diligence policies, procedur es, and processes are required for private banking accounts for non -U.S.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: persons by section 312 of the USA PATRIOT Act.  Refer to the core overview section, “Private Banking Due

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Diligence Program (Non -U.S. Persons),” page 125, for additional guidance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 252 Guidance on Obtaining and Retaining Beneficial Ownership Information , was issued by FinCEN, Board of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Governors of the Federal Reserve System, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, National Credit Union

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Administration, Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, Office of Thrift Supervision, and Securities and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Exchange Commission, in consultation with the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission, in May 2010.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The guidance cons olidates existing regulatory expectations for obtaining beneficial ownership information for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: certain accounts and customer relationships.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Private Banking — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  276 11/17/2014  named accountholder .  However, the CIP rule also provides that, based on the bank’s risk

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assessment of a new account opened by a customer that is not an individual (e.g., private

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: banking accounts opened for a PIC), the bank may need “to obtain information about” individuals with authority or control over such an account, including signatories, in order to verify the customer’s identity

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 253 and to determine whether the account is maint ained for non-

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: U.S. persons.254

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Before opening accounts, banks should collect the following information from the private

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: banking clients:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Purpose of the account.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Type of products and services to be used.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Anticipated account activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Description and history o f the source of the client ’s wealth.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Client’ s estimated net worth, including financial statements.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Current source of funds for the account.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • References or other information to confirm the reputation of the client.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Bearer Shares

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Some shell companies issue bearer shares (i.e., ownership is vested via bearer shares, which

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: allows ownership of the corporation to be conveyed by simply transferring physical possession of the shares) .  Risk mitigation of shell companies that issue bearer  shares may

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: include maintaining control of the bearer shares, entrusting the shares with a reliable independent third party, or requiring periodic certification of ownership.  Banks should

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assess the risks these relationships pose and determine the appropr iate controls .  For

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: example, in most cases banks should choose to maintain (or have an independent third party

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: maintain ) bearer shares for customers .  In rare cases involving lower -risk, well-known, long -

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: time customers, banks may find that periodically re -certifying beneficial ownership is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: effective.  A  strong CDD program is a n effective  underlying control through which banks

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: can determine the nature, purpose, and expected use of shell companies and apply

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: appropriate monitoring and documentation standards.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Convertible Shares

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Certain jurisdictions also allow for registered shares to be converted to bearer shares.  These types of entities also carry the same type of risk as bearer shares, primarily centered on the lack of transparency regarding the potential transfer of ownership or control of those shares.  Risk mitigation for relationships belonging to corporate entities with a convertibility option is essentially the same as traditional bearer shares.  Financial institutions should assess the risk posed by these relationships and implement appropriate and ongoing beneficial ownership

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 254 Refer to the core examination procedures, “Private Banking Due Diligence Program (No n-U.S. Persons),”

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: page  130, for additional guidance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Private Banking — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  277 11/17/2014  certifications, establish prudent measures as necessary to restrict conversion to bearer share

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: form without prior notification from the customer or require control of the shares  by a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reliable independent third party.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Board of Directors and Senior Management Oversight

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The board of directors ’ and senior management ’s active oversight of private banking

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activities and the creation of an appropriate corporate oversight culture are cr ucial elements

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of a sound risk management and control environment .  The purpose and objectives of the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: organization’ s private banking activities should be clearly identified and communicated by

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the board and senior management .  Well -developed goals and obje ctives should describe the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: target client base in terms of minimum net worth, investable assets, and types of products and services sought .  Goals and objectives should also specifically describe the types of clients

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the bank does  and does  not accept and sh ould establish appropriate levels of authorization for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: new-client acceptance.  Board and senior management should also be actively involved in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: establishing control and risk management goals for private banking activities, including effective audit and comp liance reviews .  Each bank should ensure that its policies,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: procedures, and processes for conducting private banking activities are evaluated and updated regularly and ensure that roles, responsibilities, and accountability are clearly

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: delineated.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Employee  compensation plans are often based on the number of new accounts established or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: on an increase in managed assets .  Board and senior management should ensure that

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: compensation plans do not create incentives for employees to ignore appropriate due

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: diligence  and account opening procedures, or possible suspicious activity relating to the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: account .  Procedures that require various levels of approval for accepting new private

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: banking accounts can minimize such opportunities.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Given the sensitive nature of private banking and the potential liability associated with it,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: banks should thoroughly investigate the background of newly hired private banking relationship managers .  During the course of employment, any indications of inappropriate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: activities should be promptl y investigated by the bank .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Additionally , when private banking relationship managers change employers, their customers

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: often move with them .  Banks bear the same potential liability for the existing customers of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: newly hired officers as they do for any new , private banking relationship.  Therefore, those

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: accounts should be promptly reviewed using the bank’ s procedures for establishing new

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: account relationships.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: MIS and reports are also important in effectively supervising and managing private banking

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: relationships and risks .  Board and senior management should review relationship manager

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: compensation reports, budget or target comparison reports, and applicable risk management

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: reports .  Private banker MIS reports should enable the relationship manager to view and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: manage the whole client and any related client relationships.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Private Banking — Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  278 11/17/2014  Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Private Banking

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the adequacy of the bank ’s systems to manage the risks associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: private banking activities, and management ’s ability to implement effective due diligence,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: monitoring, and reporting systems .  This section expands the core review of the statutory and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: regulatory requirements of private banking in order to provide a broader assessment of the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: AML risks associated with this activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 1. Review the policies, procedures, and processes related to private banking activities .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Evaluate the adequacy of the poli cies, procedures, and processes given the bank’ s private

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: banking activities and the risks they represent .  Assess whether the  controls are adequate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to reasonably protect the bank from money laundering and terrorist financing.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 2. From  a review of MIS report s (e.g., customer aggregation, policy exception and missing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: documentation, customer risk classification, unusual accounts activity, and client

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: concentrations) and internal risk rating factors, determine whether the bank effectively identifies and monitors private banking relationships, particularly those that pose a higher

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: risk for money laundering.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 3. Determine whether the bank ’s system for monitoring private banking relationships for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious activities, and for reporting of suspicious activities, is adequate given the bank’ s size, complexity, location, and types of customer relationships.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 4. Review the private banking compensation program .  Determine whether it includes

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: qualitative measures that are provided to employees to comply with account opening a nd

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: suspicious activity monitoring and reporting requirements.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 5. Review the monitoring program the bank uses to oversee the private banking relationship manager ’s personal financial condition and to detect any inappropriate activities.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 6. If appropriate, r efer to the core examination procedures , “Office of Foreign Assets

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Control,” page 152, for guidance .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Transaction Testing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 7. On the basis of the bank ’s risk assessment of its private banking activities, as well as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: prior examination and audit reports, select  a sample of private banking accounts .  The

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: sample should include the following types of accounts:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Politically exposed persons (PEP ).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Private i nvestment c ompanies (PIC ), internati onal business corporations (IBC ), and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: shell companies.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Offshore entities.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Cash-intensive businesses.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Import or export companies.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Private Banking — Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  279 11/17/2014  • Customers from or doing business in a higher -risk geographic location.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Customers listed on unusual activity monitoring reports.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Customers who have large dollar transactions and frequent funds transfers.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 8. From the sample selected, perform the following examination procedures:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Review account opening documentation and ongoing due diligence information.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Review account statements and, as necessary, specific transaction details.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Compare expected transactions with actual activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Determine whether actual activity is consistent with the nature of the customer ’s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: business.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Identify any unusual or suspicious activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 9. On the basis of examination procedures completed, including transaction testing, form a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: conclu sion about the adequacy  of policies, procedures, and processes associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: private banking relationships.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Trust and Asset Management Services  — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  280 11/17/2014  Trust and Asset Management Services — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the adequacy of the bank ’s policies, procedures, processes, and systems

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to manage the risks associated with trust and asset management255 services, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: management ’s ability to implement effective due diligence, monitoring, and reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Trust256 accounts are generally defined as a legal arrangement in which one party (the trustor

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: or grantor) transfers ownership of assets to a person or bank (the trustee) to be held or used

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: for the benefit of others .  These arrangements include the broad categories of  court -

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: supervised accounts (e.g. , executorships and guard ianships), personal trusts (e.g., living

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: trusts, trusts established under a will, and charitable tru sts), and corporate trusts (e.g., bond

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: trusteeships).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Unlike trust arrangements, agency account s are established by contract and governed by

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: contract law .  Assets are held under the terms of the contract, and legal title or ownership

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: does not transfer to the bank as agent .  Agency accounts include custody, escrow, investment

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: management,257 and safekeeping relationships .  Agency products and services may be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: offered in a traditional trust department or through other bank departments.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Customer Identification Program

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: CIP rules, which became effective October 1, 2003, apply to substantially all bank account s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: opened after that date.  The CIP rule defines an “ account ” to include cash management,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: safekeeping, custodian, and trust relationships .  The definition of account in the CIP rule

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: does not include an account for the purpose of participating in an e mployee  benefit plan

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: established under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 19 74 (ERISA).258

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: In the case of employee benefit plan accounts that are subject to ERISA that are established as trusts, the bank’s customer is the employee benefit plan trust es tablished by the employer

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to hold the assets of the employee benefit plan.  Such plans often have individual participant or beneficiary accounts.  For purposes of the CIP rule, a participant in or beneficiary of such an account is  not be deemed to be the bank’s “customer,” as such a person has  not initiated

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the relationship with the bank.  The account is  not be considered opened by the employee

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: even if a subaccount is maintained in the employee’s name, or the employee is able to contribute assets into the account, so long as the employee contribution is limited to rolling over assets from another plan, ele ctive salary deferral contributions, purchasing securities or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 255 Asset management accounts can be trust or agency accounts and are managed by the bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 256 The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency uses the broader term “fiduciary capacity” instead of “trust.”

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Fiduciary capacity includes a trustee, an executor, an administrator, a registrar of stocks and bonds, a transfer

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: agent, a guardian, an assignee, a receiver, or a custodian under a uniform gifts to minors act; an investment

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: adviser, if the bank receives a fee for its investment advice; and any capacity in which the bank possesses

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: investment discretion on behalf of another (12 CFR 9.2(e) and 12 CFR 550.30).

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 257 For purposes of national banks and savings associations, certain investment management activities, such  as

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: providing investment advice for a fee, are “fiduciary” in nature.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 258 Refer to the Interagency Interpretive Guidance on Customer Identification Program Requirements under

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Section 326 of the USA PATRIOT Act , August 28, 2005.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Trust and Asset Management Services  — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  281 11/17/2014  exercising options to purchase securities, or repaying a loan, in accordance with the terms of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the plan.  For employee benefit plan accounts that are not subject to ERISA such as employee benefi t plan accounts established by government entities, the bank’s customer is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the employer that contracts with the bank to establish the account.  By contrast, where an

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: individual opens an individual retirement account in a bank, the individual who opens the account is the bank's "customer."

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: For purposes of the CIP, the bank is not required to search the trust, escrow, or similar accounts to verify the identities of beneficiaries, but instead is only required to verify the identity of the named accountholder (the trust) .  In the case of a trust account, the customer is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the trust whether or not the bank is the trustee for the trust .  However, the CIP rule also

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: provides that, based on the bank’ s risk assessment of a new account opened by a customer

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: that is not a n individual, the bank may need “ to obtain information about ” individuals with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: authority or control over such an account, including signatories, in order to verify the customer ’s identity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 259 For example, in certain circumstances involving revocable trusts, the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank may need to gather information about the settlor, grantor, trustee, or other persons with the authority to direct the trustee, and who thus have authority or control over the account, in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: order to establish the true identity of the customer.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: In the  case of an escrow account, if a bank establishes an account in the name of a third

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: party, such as a real estate agent, who is acting as escrow agent, then the bank ’s customer is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the escrow agent .  If the bank is the escrow agent, then the person who establishes the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: account is the bank ’s customer .  For example, if the purchaser of real estate directly opens an

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: escrow account and deposits funds to be paid to the seller upon satisfaction of specified

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: conditions, the bank’ s customer is  the purchaser .  Further,  if a company in formation

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: establishes an escrow account for investors to deposit their subscriptions pending receipt of a required minimum amount, the bank’ s customer is  the company in formation (or if not yet a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: legal entity, the person opening the account on its behalf) .  However, the CIP rule also

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: provides that, based on the bank’ s risk assessment of a new account opened by a customer

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: that is not an individual , the bank may need “ to obtain information about ” individuals with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: authority or control over such an account, including signatories, in order to verify the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customer ’s identity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Risk Factors

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Trust and asset management accounts, including agency relationships, present BSA/AML

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: concerns similar to those of deposit taking, lending, and other traditional banking activities .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Concerns are primarily due to the unique relationship structures involved when the bank

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: handles trust and agency activities, such as:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Personal and court -supervised accounts.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Trust accounts  formed in the private banking department.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Asset management and investment advisory accounts.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Trust and Asset Management Services  — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  282 11/17/2014  • Global and domestic custody accounts.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Securities lending.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Employee benefit and retirement accounts.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Corporate trust accounts.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Transfer agent accounts.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Other relat ed business lines.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: As in any account relationship, money laundering risk may arise from trust and asset

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: management activities .  When misused, trust and asset management accounts can conceal the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: sources and uses of funds, as well as the identity of benefici al and legal owners .  Customers

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and account beneficiaries may try to remain anonymous in order to move illicit funds or avoid scrutiny .  For example, customers may seek a certain level of anonymity by creating

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: private i nvestment c ompanies (PIC ),

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 261 offshore trusts, or other investment entities that hide

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the true ownership or beneficial interest of the trust.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Risk Mitigation

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Management should develop policies, procedures, and processes that enable the bank to identify unusual account relationships and circumst ances, questionable assets and sources of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assets, and other potential areas of risk (e.g., offshore accounts, PIC s, asset protection trusts

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: (APT ),

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 262 agency accounts, and unidentified beneficiaries) .  While the majority of traditional

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: trust and asset managem ent accounts do not need EDD, management should be alert to those

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: situations that need additional review or research.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Customer Comparison Against Lists

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The bank must maintain required CIP information and complete the required one -time check

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of trust account names against section 314(a) search requests .  The bank should also be able

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to identify customers who may be politically exposed persons (PEP), doing business with or located in a jurisdiction designated as “ primary money laundering concern ” under section

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 311 of the USA PATRIOT  Act, or match OFAC lists.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 263 As a sound practice, the bank

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: should also determine the identity of other parties that may have control over the account, such as grantors or co -trustees .  Refer to the core overview section , “Information  Sharing ,”

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 261 For additional guidance on PICs , refer to the expanded overview section, “Business Entities (Domestic and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Foreign),” page  314.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 262 APTs are a special form of irrevocable trust, usually created (settled) offshore for the principal purposes of

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: preserving and protecting part of one’s wealth against creditors.  Title to the asset is transferred to a person

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: named as the trustee.  APTs are generally tax neutral with the ultimate function of providing for the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: beneficiaries.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 263 Management and examiners should be aware that OFAC list -matching is not a BSA requirement.  However,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: because trust systems are typically separate and distinct from bank  systems, verification of these checks on the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank system is not sufficient to ensure that these checks are also completed in the trust and asset management

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: department.  Moreover, OFAC’s position is that an account beneficiary has a future or contingent in terest in

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: funds in an account and, consistent with a bank’s risk profile, beneficiaries should be screened to assure OFAC

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: compliance.  Refer to the core overview section, “Office of Foreign Assets Control,” page 142, for additional

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: guidance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Trust and Asset Management Services  — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  283 11/17/2014  page  92, and expanded overview section, “Politically Exposed Persons ,” page 290, for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: additional  guidance.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Circumstances Warranting Enhanced Due Diligence

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Management should assess account risk on the basis of a variety of factors, which may

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: inclu de:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Type of trust or agency account and its size.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Types and frequency of transactions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Country of residence of the principals or beneficiaries, or the country where established,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: or source of funds.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Accounts and transactions that are not usual and customary  for the customer or for the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Stringent documentation, verification, and transaction monitoring procedures should be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: established for accounts that management considers as higher  risk.  Typically, employee

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: benefit accounts and court -supervised accounts  are among the lowest BSA/AML risks.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The following are examples of situations in which EDD may be appropriate:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Bank is entering into a relationship with a new customer.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Account principals or beneficiaries reside in a foreign jurisdiction, or the trust or i ts

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: funding mechanisms are established offshore.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Assets or transactions are atypical for the type and character of the customer.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Account type, size, assets, or transactions are atypical for the bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • International funds transfers are conducted, particularly  through offshore funding

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: sources.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Accounts are funded with easily transportable assets such as gemstones, precious metals,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: coins, artwork, rare stamps, or negotiable instruments.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Accounts or relationships are maintained in which the identities of the principals, or beneficiaries, or sources of funds are unknown or cannot easily be determined.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Accounts benefit charit able organizations or other nongovernmental organizations (NGO )

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: that may be used as a conduit for illegal activities.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Interest on lawyers ’ trust accounts (IOLTA) holding and processing significant dollar

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: amounts.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Account assets that include PICs.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • PEPs are parties to any accounts or transactions.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 264 For addition al guidance, refer to the expanded overview section, “Nongovernmental Organizations and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Charities,” page  311.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Trust and Asset Management Services  — Examination Proce dures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  284 11/17/2014  Examination Procedures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Trust and Asset Management Services

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the adequacy of the bank ’s policies, procedures, processes, and systems

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to manage the risks associated with trust and asset management265 services, and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: management ’s ability to implement effective due diligence, monitoring, and reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: If this is a standalone trust examination, refer to the core examination procedures , “Scoping

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and Planning ,” page  15, for comprehensive guidance on the BSA/AML examination scope .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: In such instances, the trust examination may need  to cover additional areas, including

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: training, the BSA compliance officer, independent review, and follow -up items.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 1. Review the policies, procedures, and processes related to trust and asset management

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: services .  Evaluate the adequacy of the policies, p rocedures, and processes given the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank’ s trust and asset management activities and the risks they present .  Assess whether

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: the controls are adequate to reasonably protect the bank from money laundering and

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: terrorist financing.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 2. Review the bank ’s procedures for gathering additional identification information, when

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: necessary, about the settlor, grantor, trustee, or other persons with authority to direct a trustee, and who thus have authority or control over the account, in order to establish a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: true identit y of the customer.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 3. From a review of MIS and internal risk rating factors, determine whether the bank

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: effectively identifies and monitors trust and asset management relationships, particularly

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: those that pose a higher  risk for money laundering.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 4. Determine how the bank includes trust and asset management relationships in a bank-wide or, if appropriate, firm -wide BSA/AML aggregation systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 5. Determine whether the bank ’s system for monitoring trust and asset management

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: relationships for suspicious  activities, and for reporting of suspicious activities, is

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: adequate given the bank ’s size, complexity, location, and types of customer relationships.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 6. If appropriate, refer to the core examination procedures , “Office of Fo reign Assets

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Control,” page 152, for guidance .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Transaction Testing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 7. On the basis of the bank ’s risk assessment of its trust and asset management

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: relationships, as well as prior examination and audit reports, select a sample of higher -

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: risk trust and asset management services relationsh ips.  Include relationships with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: grantors and co- trustees, if they have authority or control, as well as any higher -risk

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: assets such as private i nvestment c ompanies (PIC ) or asset protection trusts .  From the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: sample selected, perform the following examinat ion procedures:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 265 Asset management accounts can be trust or agency accounts and are managed by the bank.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Trust and Asset Management Services  — Examination Proce dures

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  285 11/17/2014  • Review account opening documentation, including the CIP , to ensure that adequate

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: due diligence has been performed and that appropriate records are maintained.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Review account statements and, as necessary, specific transaction details .  Compare

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: expected transactions with actual activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Determine whether actual activity is consistent with the nature of the customer ’s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: business and the stated purpose of the account.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Identify any unusual or suspicious activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 8. On the basis of examination procedures completed, including transaction testing, form a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: conclusion about the adequacy of policies, procedures, and processes associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: trust and asset management relationships.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Nonresident Aliens and Foreign Individuals — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  286 11/17/2014  EXPANDED EXAMINATION  OVERVIEW  AND

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: PROCEDURES FOR PERSO NS AND ENTITIES

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Nonresident Aliens and Foreign Individuals — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Objective.  Assess the adequacy of the bank ’s systems to manage the risks associated with

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transactions involving acc ounts held by nonresident aliens  (NRA ) and foreign individuals,

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: and management ’s ability to implement effective due diligence, monitoring, and reporting

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: systems.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Foreign individuals maintaining relationships with U.S. banks can be divided into two

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: categori es: resident aliens and nonresident aliens .  For definitional purposes, an NRA is a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: non-U.S. citizen who: (i) is not a lawful permanent resident of the United States during the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: calendar year and who does not meet the substantial presence test,266 or (ii) has  not been

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: issued an alien registration receipt card, also known as a green card.  The IRS determines the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: tax liabilities of a foreign person and officially defines the person as a “ resident ” or

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: “nonresident.”

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Although NRAs are not permanent residents, they  may have a legitimate need to establish an

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: account relationship with a U.S. bank.  NRAs use bank products and services for asset preservation (e.g., mitigating losses due to exchange rates), business expansion, and investments .  The amount of NRA deposits  in the U.S. banking system has been estimated to

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: range from hundreds of billions of dollars to about $1 trillion.  Even at the low end of the range, the magnitude is substantial, both in terms of the U.S. banking system and the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: economy.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Risk Factors

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks  may find it more difficult to verify and authenticate an NRA accountholder ’s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: identification, source of funds, and source of wealth, which may result in BSA/AML risks.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The NRA ’s home country may also heighten the account risk, depending on the secrecy law s

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: of that country .  Because the NRA is expected to reside outside of the United States, funds

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: transfers or the use of foreign automated teller machines (ATM) may be more frequent .  The

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: BSA/AML risk may be further heightened if the NRA is a politically expo sed person (PEP) .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Refer to the expanded examination procedures , “Politically Exposed Persons ,” page  294, for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: further information.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: 266 A foreign national is a resident alien if the individua l is physically present in the United States for at least 31

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: days in the current calendar year and present 183 days or more based on counting: all days present during the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: current year, plus one -third of the days present in the preceding year, plus one -sixth of the days present in the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: second preceding year.  Certain days of presence are disregarded, such as (i) days spent in the United States for

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: a medical condition that developed while the foreign national was present in the United States and unable to

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: leave, (ii) days regular commuters spend traveling to or from Canada or Mexico, (iii) a day of less than 24 hours

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: spent while in transit between two locations outside the United States., and (iv) days when the foreign national

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: was an exempt individual.  The individual is considered a resident alien for federal income and employment tax

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: purposes from the first day of physical presence in the United States in the year that the test is satisfied.  Refer

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: to the IRS Web site .

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Nonresident Aliens and Foreign Individuals — Overview

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: FFIEC BSA/AML Examination Manual  287 11/17/2014  Risk Mitigation

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: Banks should establish policies, procedures, and processes that provide for sound due

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: diligence and verificat ion practices, adequate risk assessment of NRA accounts, and ongoing

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: monitoring and reporting of unusual or suspicious activities .  The following factors are to be

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: considered when determining the risk level of an NRA account:

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Accountholder ’s home country.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Types of products and services used.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Forms of identification.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Source of wealth and funds.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: • Unusual account activity.

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: NRA customers may request W -8 status for U.S. tax withholding .  In such cases, the NRA

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: customer completes a W -8 form, which attests to the customer ’s foreign and U.S. tax -exempt

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: status .  While it is an IRS form, a W -8 is not sent to the IRS, but is maintained on file at the

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: bank to support the lack of any tax withholding from earnings.267

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: The bank’ s CIP should detail the identification requirem ents for opening an account for a

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
content: non-U.S. person, including an NRA .  The program should include the use of documentary

name: 252222333-Bank-Secrecy-Act-Anti-Money-Laundering-Examination-Manual-2014
